results.title: Early marriage
results.brief_description: Deals with teenage marriage, high school counselling and classroom teaching of marriage preparation. Failures are often due to parents and schools making young marriages difficult, rather than ensuring their success. Discusses types of marriage, religious and civil. Symbolism of the ring and post nuptial ceremonies, which should demonstrate the approval and support of parents and friends.

results.title: Early interactions (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Philps, Victor Lockwood, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
H.R. Schaffer introduces five experiments which demonstrate the importance of synchronisation between mother and baby. The experiments also show that it is often the baby who initiates the interactions.

results.title: Early days yet: a profile of the poet Allen Curnow
results.creator_credit: Shirley Horrocks and Point of View Productions
results.brief_description: This is a beautifully presented documentary about the life and memories of the highly acclaimed New Zealand poet, critic and anthropologist, Allen Curnow. At the age of almost 90, Allen Curnow still wrote poetry using “a ball-point, quantities of A4 paper, and a typewriter”. Charming, gentle and retiring, family man and serious poet, Allen Curnow has won many awards in the world of literature including seven New Zealand Book Awards and the first person outside of Britain to receive the Queen’s Gold Medal for Poetry. The program features Curnow reading several of his poems accompanied by evocative and emotive images to illustrate his writings which often reflect memories of people, places or events from his past. With his quiet sense of humor and reminiscing, and through interviews with his wife Jenny, and fellow poets including Bill Manhire, C.K. Stead, Ian Wedde, Leigh Davis and Elizabeth Smither, Allen Curnow allows us a glimpse into both his personal and his creative life. The documentary takes its title from his latest publication “Early days yet: new and collected poems 1941-1997”. Sadly Allen Curnow passed away on 23 September 2001, three months after completion of this film. Contains archival footage and some scenes in b&w.

results.title: Early childhood
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personality”.
The experiences of pre-school children play a role in all aspects of their personality development. While there are many personality traits developing during this age period, several are of special significance: dependence, identification, aggression, fear and anxiety.

results.title: Early Amateur Sound Film (1936–37)
results.brief_description: Amateur filmmaker Archie Stewart used an RCA Sound Camera to document family life from 1935. A member of the Amateur Cinema League, in 1937 he published one of the first articles on amateur sound, ‘A Talkie Movie Maker Speaks’, in the league’s magazine.

constellations_other.name: Amateur hour
constellations_other.description: Early sound equipment allowed filmmakers and amateurs alike the ability to experiment often with affordable 16mm film.

results.title: Early actualities [Silent]
results.brief_description: This is a compilation of early short silent films made between 1900-1905 about newsworthy events. Each “short” is preceded by explanatory titles as follows: THE BOER WAR: DEPARTURE OF THE GORDON HIGHLANDERS (OCT. 1899); LORD ROBERTS ARRIVES IN CAPE TOWN (JAN.1900); STREET SCENE IN LEEDS (C.1903); SCENE ON BRIGHTON PIER (C.1898); FIRE BRIGADE SCENE IN BRITAIN, FRANCE AND U.S.A. (C.1896-1902); FUNERAL OF QUEEN VICTORIA (FEB.1901).

results.title: Early abortion
results.brief_description: Uses scenes from a question-and-answer session and from an abortion procedure in order to explain a typical atravmatic abortion procedure. Narrated by Adrienne Barbeau and animation by Robert Greenberg

results.title: Earliest times to 1066
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English History”.
This film discusses the building of Anglo-Saxon England, with emphasis on the many different peoples and cultures which contribute to the development of the English nation. This film uses authentic landmarks and historical material from 1900 B.C. to 1000 A.D. as well as brief re-enactments of important historical events to give a compressed picture of England and its people before the Norman Conquest.

results.creator_credit: John G. Fuller and United States Information Agency

results.title: Earl of Home
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
In an interview with Robert McKenzie, the Earl of Home, Britain’s Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations, discusses present and future trends of the British Commonwealth and talks about some of the links and common aims that bind this family of nations together.
